ChatGPT said:

Awesome — let’s get that scraper going for the Revue Cinema’s All Films page. We'll keep things modular and clean so it's easy to expand later for other theaters.

🛠️ Step-by-Step Plan to Build the Revue Scraper

We'll write a script that:

  1. Downloads the HTML of the films page

  2. Parses each film block to extract:

    • Title

    • Showtimes (dates and times)

    • URL to the film page (if available)

  3. Outputs the data in a structured format (like a list of dictionaries or JSON)

🔧 Let's start with this basic Python scraper:

python
import requests
from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
from datetime import datetime

URL = "https://revuecinema.ca/films/"
HEADERS = {
    "User-Agent": "Mozilla/5.0"
}

def scrape_revue_films():
    response = requests.get(URL, headers=HEADERS)
    response.raise_for_status()

    soup = BeautifulSoup(response.text, "html.parser")
    film_cards = soup.select(".event-block")  # These divs wrap each film listing

    films = []

    for card in film_cards:
        title_tag = card.select_one(".event-title")
        showtimes_tags = card.select(".event-times .event-time")
        link_tag = card.select_one("a")

        title = title_tag.text.strip() if title_tag else "Untitled"
        link = link_tag["href"] if link_tag else None

        # Extract all showtimes
        showtimes = []
        for time_tag in showtimes_tags:
            raw_time = time_tag.text.strip()
            showtimes.append(raw_time)

        films.append({
            "title": title,
            "link": link,
            "showtimes": showtimes
        })

    return films

if __name__ == "__main__":
    data = scrape_revue_films()
    for film in data:
        print(film)

✅ Example Output

json
{
  "title": "Stop Making Sense",
  "link": "https://revuecinema.ca/films/stop-making-sense/",
  "showtimes": ["April 10 @ 7:00PM", "April 11 @ 9:15PM"]
}

🧰 Option 2: Use Selenium to Load Pages Like a Browser

Selenium works more like a real browser and might work even if requests fails. To set it up:

  1. Open terminal or CMD:

    bash
    pip install selenium

  2. Download ChromeDriver that matches your version of Chrome: https://sites.google.com/chromium.org/driver/

  3. Save this script as revue_selenium.py:

python
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.service import Service
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.options import Options
import time

# Path to your downloaded chromedriver.exe
CHROMEDRIVER_PATH = "D:/path/to/chromedriver.exe"

options = Options()
options.add_argument("--headless")  # comment this line out if you want to see the browser

service = Service(CHROMEDRIVER_PATH)
driver = webdriver.Chrome(service=service, options=options)

driver.get("https://revuecinema.ca/films/")
time.sleep(5)  # Wait for JavaScript to load

# Get film titles
events = driver.find_elements(By.CLASS_NAME, "event-block")

for event in events:
    title = event.find_element(By.CLASS_NAME, "event-title").text
    print("🎬", title)

driver.quit()

Update the CHROMEDRIVER_PATH with where you saved the .exe.

✅ Step-by-Step: Set Up Selenium on Windows

🧩 Step 1: Install Selenium

Open Command Prompt and run:

bash
pip install selenium

🧱 Step 2: Download ChromeDriver

  1. Find your Chrome version:

    • Open Chrome → go to chrome://settings/help

  2. Go to the matching ChromeDriver download page:
    👉 https://sites.google.com/chromium.org/driver/

  3. Download and unzip it

  4. Save it somewhere like: D:\tools\chromedriver.exe

📄 Step 3: Save and Run This Script

Here’s a working script using Selenium:

python
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.service import Service
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.options import Options
import time

# Set the path to where you saved chromedriver.exe
CHROMEDRIVER_PATH = "D:/tools/chromedriver.exe"

# Optional: run without opening a browser window
options = Options()
options.add_argument("--headless")
options.add_argument("--no-sandbox")
options.add_argument("--disable-dev-shm-usage")

service = Service(CHROMEDRIVER_PATH)
driver = webdriver.Chrome(service=service, options=options)

# Open the Revue films page
driver.get("https://revuecinema.ca/films/")
time.sleep(3)  # Wait for JavaScript to load

films = []

events = driver.find_elements(By.CLASS_NAME, "event-block")
for event in events:
    title = event.find_element(By.CLASS_NAME, "event-title").text
    link = event.find_element(By.TAG_NAME, "a").get_attribute("href")
    times = event.find_elements(By.CLASS_NAME, "event-time")
    showtimes = [t.text for t in times]

    films.append({
        "title": title,
        "link": link,
        "showtimes": showtimes
    })

driver.quit()

# Print the results
for film in films:
    print("🎬", film["title"])
    print("🔗", film["link"])
    print("🕒 Showtimes:")
    for time in film["showtimes"]:
        print("  -", time)
    print("-" * 40)

ChatGPT said:

Absolutely — here’s the full, updated Selenium script with:

  • ✅ Smart waiting (instead of sleep)

  • ✅ Clear logging to show how many films were found

  • ✅ Outputs: title, link, showtimes

🧾 Copy & Paste This Into a .py File (e.g., revue_scraper.py):

python
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.service import Service
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.options import Options
from selenium.webdriver.support.ui import WebDriverWait
from selenium.webdriver.support import expected_conditions as EC

# Set this to where your chromedriver.exe is located
CHROMEDRIVER_PATH = "D:/tools/chromedriver.exe"

# Set up Chrome options
options = Options()
# Comment this out if you want to see the browser window
# options.add_argument("--headless")
options.add_argument("--no-sandbox")
options.add_argument("--disable-dev-shm-usage")

# Set up and launch Chrome
service = Service(CHROMEDRIVER_PATH)
driver = webdriver.Chrome(service=service, options=options)

# Load the Revue Cinema films page
driver.get("https://revuecinema.ca/films/")

# Wait until the film listings have loaded
WebDriverWait(driver, 10).until(
    EC.presence_of_element_located((By.CLASS_NAME, "event-block"))
)

# Scrape film data
films = []
events = driver.find_elements(By.CLASS_NAME, "event-block")
print(f"✅ Found {len(events)} film(s).\n")

for event in events:
    title = event.find_element(By.CLASS_NAME, "event-title").text
    link = event.find_element(By.TAG_NAME, "a").get_attribute("href")
    times = event.find_elements(By.CLASS_NAME, "event-time")
    showtimes = [t.text.strip() for t in times]

    films.append({
        "title": title,
        "link": link,
        "showtimes": showtimes
    })

driver.quit()

# Output the results
for film in films:
    print(f"🎬 {film['title']}")
    print(f"🔗 {film['link']}")
    print("🕒 Showtimes:")
    for time in film["showtimes"]:
        print(f"  - {time}")
    print("-" * 40)

from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.service import Service
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.options import Options
from selenium.webdriver.support.ui import WebDriverWait
from selenium.webdriver.support import expected_conditions as EC

CHROMEDRIVER_PATH = "D:/tools/chromedriver.exe"

options = Options()
# Comment this out to see the browser
# options.add_argument("--headless")
options.add_argument("--no-sandbox")
options.add_argument("--disable-dev-shm-usage")

service = Service(CHROMEDRIVER_PATH)
driver = webdriver.Chrome(service=service, options=options)

driver.get("https://revuecinema.ca/films/")

print("📄 Page loaded:", driver.title)

# Adjusted selector to better match real site
WebDriverWait(driver, 10).until(
    EC.presence_of_element_located((By.CLASS_NAME, "fusion-post-wrapper"))
)

films = []
events = driver.find_elements(By.CLASS_NAME, "fusion-post-wrapper")
print(f"✅ Found {len(events)} film(s).\n")

for event in events:
    title = event.find_element(By.CLASS_NAME, "entry-title").text
    link = event.find_element(By.TAG_NAME, "a").get_attribute("href")
    # Revue doesn't list showtimes directly here — we'll extract from detail page later
    films.append({
        "title": title,
        "link": link,
        "showtimes": []
    })

driver.save_screenshot("revue_debug.png")
driver.quit()

for film in films:
    print(f"🎬 {film['title']}")
    print(f"🔗 {film['link']}")
    print("🕒 Showtimes: (coming in next step)")
    print("-" * 40)

✅ Full Working Code (Basic Version)

python
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.service import Service
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.options import Options
from selenium.webdriver.support.ui import WebDriverWait
from selenium.webdriver.support import expected_conditions as EC

# Set the path to where your chromedriver.exe is located
CHROMEDRIVER_PATH = "D:/tools/chromedriver.exe"

# Set up Chrome options
options = Options()
# Comment this out if you want to see the browser
# options.add_argument("--headless")
options.add_argument("--no-sandbox")
options.add_argument("--disable-dev-shm-usage")

# Set up and launch Chrome
service = Service(CHROMEDRIVER_PATH)
driver = webdriver.Chrome(service=service, options=options)

# Open the Revue Cinema films page
driver.get("https://revuecinema.ca/films/")
print("📄 Page loaded:", driver.title)

# Wait until the film titles are present on the page
WebDriverWait(driver, 10).until(
    EC.presence_of_element_located((By.CLASS_NAME, "entry-title"))
)

# Find all film titles
titles = driver.find_elements(By.CLASS_NAME, "entry-title")
print(f"✅ Found {len(titles)} film(s).\n")

# Loop through and print the titles and links
for title_element in titles:
    title = title_element.text
    link = title_element.find_element(By.TAG_NAME, "a").get_attribute("href")
    print(f"🎬 {title}")
    print(f"🔗 {link}")
    print("-" * 40)

driver.quit()

  • Loads the Revue Cinema "All Films" page

  • Waits until movie titles appear

  • Prints each title and its link

✅ Let's Fix It:

We'll change the selector to target the actual film links more reliably. Based on what’s live right now on https://revuecinema.ca/films/, the titles are inside <h2> tags with class="fusion-post-title entry-title".

So we'll simplify the selector and wait for any link inside a film title.

🧾 Copy and Run This Version:

python
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.service import Service
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.options import Options
from selenium.webdriver.support.ui import WebDriverWait
from selenium.webdriver.support import expected_conditions as EC

CHROMEDRIVER_PATH = "D:/tools/chromedriver.exe"

options = Options()
# Leave visible so we can debug if needed
# options.add_argument("--headless")
options.add_argument("--no-sandbox")
options.add_argument("--disable-dev-shm-usage")

service = Service(CHROMEDRIVER_PATH)
driver = webdriver.Chrome(service=service, options=options)

driver.get("https://revuecinema.ca/films/")
print("📄 Page loaded:", driver.title)

# Save screenshot before anything
driver.save_screenshot("revue_debug.png")

# Wait for ANY film card link to appear
try:
    WebDriverWait(driver, 10).until(
        EC.presence_of_element_located((By.CSS_SELECTOR, "h2.fusion-post-title.entry-title a"))
    )
except:
    print("❌ Still couldn't find any movie links.")
    driver.save_screenshot("revue_debug_fail.png")
    driver.quit()
    exit()

# Now get all titles + links
film_links = driver.find_elements(By.CSS_SELECTOR, "h2.fusion-post-title.entry-title a")
print(f"✅ Found {len(film_links)} film(s).\n")

for link in film_links:
    title = link.text.strip()
    url = link.get_attribute("href")
    print(f"🎬 {title}")
    print(f"🔗 {url}")
    print("-" * 40)

driver.quit()

✅ Final Working Scraper Code

python
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.service import Service
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.options import Options
import time

CHROMEDRIVER_PATH = "D:/tools/chromedriver.exe"

options = Options()
# options.add_argument("--headless")  # Uncomment if you want headless mode
options.add_argument("--no-sandbox")
options.add_argument("--disable-dev-shm-usage")

service = Service(CHROMEDRIVER_PATH)
driver = webdriver.Chrome(service=service, options=options)

# Open the films page
driver.get("https://revuecinema.ca/films/")
print("📄 Page loaded:", driver.title)

time.sleep(5)  # Let all JavaScript render

# Grab all film blocks
film_blocks = driver.find_elements(By.CLASS_NAME, "brxe-sdlpwn")
print(f"✅ Found {len(film_blocks)} films.\n")

films = []

for block in film_blocks:
    try:
        title_tag = block.find_element(By.TAG_NAME, "h5").find_element(By.TAG_NAME, "a")
        title = title_tag.text.strip()
        link = title_tag.get_attribute("href")
    except:
        title, link = "Untitled", None

    try:
        showtime_tag = block.find_element(By.CLASS_NAME, "brxe-ndxpjc")
        showtime = showtime_tag.text.strip()
    except:
        showtime = "No time listed"

    films.append({
        "title": title,
        "link": link,
        "showtime": showtime
    })

driver.quit()

# Print results
for film in films:
    print(f"🎬 {film['title']}")
    print(f"🔗 {film['link']}")
    print(f"🕒 Showtime: {film['showtime']}")
    print("-" * 40)

🕒 Showtime: Wed Apr 09, 06:00 PM

✅ Updated Script (Auto-load all films)

python
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.service import Service
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.options import Options
from selenium.common.exceptions import ElementClickInterceptedException, NoSuchElementException
import time

CHROMEDRIVER_PATH = "D:/tools/chromedriver.exe"

options = Options()
# options.add_argument("--headless")
options.add_argument("--no-sandbox")
options.add_argument("--disable-dev-shm-usage")

service = Service(CHROMEDRIVER_PATH)
driver = webdriver.Chrome(service=service, options=options)

driver.get("https://revuecinema.ca/films/")
print("📄 Page loaded:", driver.title)

# === AUTO-CLICK "LOAD MORE" ===
while True:
    try:
        load_more = driver.find_element(By.XPATH, "//button[contains(text(), 'Load More')]")
        driver.execute_script("arguments[0].click();", load_more)
        print("🔄 Clicked 'Load More'...")
        time.sleep(2)  # Wait for content to load
    except (NoSuchElementException, ElementClickInterceptedException):
        print("✅ No more 'Load More' buttons.")
        break

# Let JS settle
time.sleep(2)

# === SCRAPE FILMS ===
film_blocks = driver.find_elements(By.CLASS_NAME, "brxe-sdlpwn")
print(f"🎬 Found {len(film_blocks)} total films.\n")

films = []

for block in film_blocks:
    try:
        title_tag = block.find_element(By.TAG_NAME, "h5").find_element(By.TAG_NAME, "a")
        title = title_tag.text.strip()
        link = title_tag.get_attribute("href")
    except:
        title, link = "Untitled", None

    try:
        showtime_tag = block.find_element(By.CLASS_NAME, "brxe-ndxpjc")
        showtime = showtime_tag.text.strip()
    except:
        showtime = "No time listed"

    films.append({
        "title": title,
        "link": link,
        "showtime": showtime
    })

driver.quit()

# === OUTPUT ===
for film in films:
    print(f"🎬 {film['title']}")
    print(f"🔗 {film['link']}")
    print(f"🕒 Showtime: {film['showtime']}")
    print("-" * 40)

🔍 What’s New:

  • while True loop clicks the "Load More" button until it's gone

  • Handles errors if the button vanishes or can't be clicked

  • Then continues scraping all visible film cards

Try this one and let me know how many listings it grabs! From there, we can save the output or start integrating other theaters. 🧠🎬

✅ Auto-Loader With Count Check:

python
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.service import Service
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.options import Options
from selenium.webdriver.common.action_chains import ActionChains
from selenium.webdriver.support.ui import WebDriverWait
from selenium.webdriver.support import expected_conditions as EC
import time

CHROMEDRIVER_PATH = "D:/tools/chromedriver.exe"

options = Options()
# options.add_argument("--headless")
options.add_argument("--no-sandbox")
options.add_argument("--disable-dev-shm-usage")

service = Service(CHROMEDRIVER_PATH)
driver = webdriver.Chrome(service=service, options=options)
wait = WebDriverWait(driver, 10)

driver.get("https://revuecinema.ca/films/")
print("📄 Page loaded:", driver.title)

# === AUTO-CLICK "LOAD MORE" ===
last_count = 0
max_attempts = 10
attempts = 0

while attempts < max_attempts:
    try:
        film_blocks = driver.find_elements(By.CLASS_NAME, "brxe-sdlpwn")
        current_count = len(film_blocks)

        # Try clicking "Load More" if the count increased
        load_more = wait.until(
            EC.element_to_be_clickable((By.XPATH, "//button[contains(text(), 'Load More')]"))
        )
        ActionChains(driver).move_to_element(load_more).perform()
        driver.execute_script("arguments[0].click();", load_more)
        print("🔄 Clicked 'Load More'...")

        time.sleep(3)  # Let content load

        film_blocks = driver.find_elements(By.CLASS_NAME, "brxe-sdlpwn")
        if len(film_blocks) == current_count:
            print("⏹ No new films loaded — stopping.")
            break

        last_count = current_count
        attempts += 1

    except Exception as e:
        print("✅ Done clicking or Load More not found.")
        break

# === SCRAPE FILMS ===
film_blocks = driver.find_elements(By.CLASS_NAME, "brxe-sdlpwn")
print(f"🎬 Found {len(film_blocks)} total films.\n")

films = []

for block in film_blocks:
    try:
        title_tag = block.find_element(By.TAG_NAME, "h5").find_element(By.TAG_NAME, "a")
        title = title_tag.text.strip()
        link = title_tag.get_attribute("href")
    except:
        title, link = "Untitled", None

    try:
        showtime_tag = block.find_element(By.CLASS_NAME, "brxe-ndxpjc")
        showtime = showtime_tag.text.strip()
    except:
        showtime = "No time listed"

    films.append({
        "title": title,
        "link": link,
        "showtime": showtime
    })

driver.quit()

# === OUTPUT ===
for film in films:
    print(f"🎬 {film['title']}")
    print(f"🔗 {film['link']}")
    print(f"🕒 Showtime: {film['showtime']}")
    print("-" * 40)

🧾 Paste This Full Script

python
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.service import Service
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.options import Options
from selenium.webdriver.common.action_chains import ActionChains
from selenium.webdriver.support.ui import WebDriverWait
from selenium.webdriver.support import expected_conditions as EC
import time

CHROMEDRIVER_PATH = "D:/tools/chromedriver.exe"

options = Options()
# options.add_argument("--headless")  # Uncomment to run headless
options.add_argument("--no-sandbox")
options.add_argument("--disable-dev-shm-usage")

service = Service(CHROMEDRIVER_PATH)
driver = webdriver.Chrome(service=service, options=options)
wait = WebDriverWait(driver, 10)

driver.get("https://revuecinema.ca/films/")
print("📄 Page loaded:", driver.title)

# === CLICK "LOAD MORE" UNTIL DONE ===
max_clicks = 10
clicks = 0

while clicks < max_clicks:
    try:
        load_more = driver.find_element(By.XPATH, "//a[text()='Load More']")
        ActionChains(driver).move_to_element(load_more).perform()
        time.sleep(1)
        load_more.click()
        print("🔄 Clicked 'Load More'")
        time.sleep(3)  # Wait for new content to load
        clicks += 1
    except:
        print("✅ 'Load More' button not found or done loading.")
        break

# === SCRAPE FILM INFO ===
film_blocks = driver.find_elements(By.CLASS_NAME, "brxe-sdlpwn")
print(f"🎬 Found {len(film_blocks)} total films.\n")

films = []

for block in film_blocks:
    try:
        title_tag = block.find_element(By.TAG_NAME, "h5").find_element(By.TAG_NAME, "a")
        title = title_tag.text.strip()
        link = title_tag.get_attribute("href")
    except:
        title, link = "Untitled", None

    try:
        showtime_tag = block.find_element(By.CLASS_NAME, "brxe-ndxpjc")
        showtime = showtime_tag.text.strip()
    except:
        showtime = "No time listed"

    films.append({
        "title": title,
        "link": link,
        "showtime": showtime
    })

driver.quit()

# === OUTPUT ===
for film in films:
    print(f"🎬 {film['title']}")
    print(f"🔗 {film['link']}")
    print(f"🕒 Showtime: {film['showtime']}")
    print("-" * 40)

python
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.service import Service
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.options import Options
from selenium.webdriver.common.action_chains import ActionChains
from selenium.webdriver.support.ui import WebDriverWait
from selenium.webdriver.support import expected_conditions as EC
import json
import time

# === SETUP ===
CHROMEDRIVER_PATH = "D:/tools/chromedriver.exe"  # <-- Update this if needed

options = Options()
# options.add_argument("--headless")  # Uncomment for headless mode
options.add_argument("--no-sandbox")
options.add_argument("--disable-dev-shm-usage")

service = Service(CHROMEDRIVER_PATH)
driver = webdriver.Chrome(service=service, options=options)
wait = WebDriverWait(driver, 10)

# === LOAD PAGE ===
driver.get("https://revuecinema.ca/films/")
print("📄 Page loaded:", driver.title)

# === CLICK "LOAD MORE" UNTIL DONE ===
max_clicks = 10
clicks = 0

while clicks < max_clicks:
    try:
        load_more = driver.find_element(By.XPATH, "//a[text()='Load More']")
        ActionChains(driver).move_to_element(load_more).perform()
        time.sleep(1)
        load_more.click()
        print("🔄 Clicked 'Load More'")
        time.sleep(3)  # Wait for new content to load
        clicks += 1
    except:
        print("✅ 'Load More' button not found or done loading.")
        break

# === SCRAPE FILM INFO ===
film_blocks = driver.find_elements(By.CLASS_NAME, "brxe-sdlpwn")
print(f"🎬 Found {len(film_blocks)} total films.\n")

films = []

for block in film_blocks:
    try:
        title_tag = block.find_element(By.TAG_NAME, "h5").find_element(By.TAG_NAME, "a")
        title = title_tag.text.strip()
        link = title_tag.get_attribute("href")
    except:
        title, link = "Untitled", None

    try:
        showtime_tag = block.find_element(By.CLASS_NAME, "brxe-ndxpjc")
        showtime = showtime_tag.text.strip()
    except:
        showtime = "No time listed"

    films.append({
        "title": title,
        "link": link,
        "showtime": showtime
    })

driver.quit()

# === PRINT RESULTS (OPTIONAL) ===
for film in films:
    print(f"🎬 {film['title']}")
    print(f"🔗 {film['link']}")
    print(f"🕒 Showtime: {film['showtime']}")
    print("-" * 40)

# === SAVE TO JSON ===
with open("revue_films.json", "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    json.dump(films, f, indent=2, ensure_ascii=False)

print("💾 Saved film data to revue_films.json")

  • 🕒 Dates & times

  • 🔗 Clickable links to more info

We’ll group it into a simple layout that's easy to browse — think of it like a mini "what's playing" calendar.

✅ Step 1: Read the JSON and Generate HTML

Here’s a Python script that:

  • Loads your revue_films.json

  • Sorts the films by date & time

  • Outputs an HTML file: revue_films.html

🧾 Copy & Paste This Script (e.g., generate_html.py)

python
import json
from datetime import datetime
from collections import defaultdict

# === Load JSON ===
with open("revue_films.json", "r", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    films = json.load(f)

# === Group by date ===
calendar = defaultdict(list)

for film in films:
    raw = film["showtime"]
    try:
        dt = datetime.strptime(raw, "%a %b %d, %I:%M %p")
    except:
        try:
            dt = datetime.strptime(raw, "%a %b %d, %H:%M %p")
        except:
            continue  # skip badly formatted

    date_key = dt.strftime("%A, %B %d")
    time_str = dt.strftime("%I:%M %p")
    calendar[date_key].append({
        "title": film["title"],
        "link": film["link"],
        "time": time_str
    })

# === Sort by date ===
sorted_days = sorted(calendar.items(), key=lambda x: datetime.strptime(x[0], "%A, %B %d"))

# === Generate HTML ===
html = """<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <title>Revue Cinema Schedule</title>
  <style>
    body { font-family: sans-serif; padding: 2rem; background: #f9f9f9; }
    h2 { border-bottom: 1px solid #ccc; padding-bottom: 5px; }
    .film { margin: 0.5rem 0; }
    .time { font-weight: bold; margin-right: 1rem; }
    a { text-decoration: none; color: #333; }
  </style>
</head>
<body>
  <h1>🎬 Revue Cinema Schedule</h1>
"""

for date, films_on_day in sorted_days:
    html += f"<h2>{date}</h2>\n"
    for film in sorted(films_on_day, key=lambda f: f["time"]):
        html += f"<div class='film'><span class='time'>{film['time']}</span><a href='{film['link']}' target='_blank'>{film['title']}</a></div>\n"

html += "</body></html>"

# === Save to HTML file ===
with open("revue_films.html", "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    f.write(html)

print("✅ Created revue_films.html — open it in your browser!")

  • Or just double-click it locally!

Awesome — here's a full Selenium-based scraper for Paradise Theatre's calendar page that:

✅ Loads all events
✅ Extracts:

  • 🎬 Title

  • 🗓️ Date and time

  • 🔗 Link to the event

✅ Saves to paradise_films.json
✅ Uses the same format as your Revue data (so it can be merged later!)

🧾 Full Code — paradise_scraper.py

python
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.service import Service
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.options import Options
from selenium.webdriver.support.ui import WebDriverWait
from selenium.webdriver.support import expected_conditions as EC
import json
import time

CHROMEDRIVER_PATH = "D:/tools/chromedriver.exe"  # <-- Update if needed

options = Options()
# options.add_argument("--headless")  # Uncomment to run headless
options.add_argument("--no-sandbox")
options.add_argument("--disable-dev-shm-usage")

service = Service(CHROMEDRIVER_PATH)
driver = webdriver.Chrome(service=service, options=options)
wait = WebDriverWait(driver, 15)

driver.get("https://paradiseonbloor.com/calendar/")
print("📄 Page loaded:", driver.title)

# Let JS load Eventbrite events
time.sleep(6)

# Paradise events are inside elements with class 'event'
events = driver.find_elements(By.CLASS_NAME, "event-item")
print(f"✅ Found {len(events)} events\n")

films = []

for event in events:
    try:
        title = event.find_element(By.CLASS_NAME, "event-title").text.strip()
    except:
        title = "Untitled"

    try:
        date = event.find_element(By.CLASS_NAME, "event-date").text.strip()
        time_el = event.find_element(By.CLASS_NAME, "event-time").text.strip()
        showtime = f"{date}, {time_el}"
    except:
        showtime = "Unknown"

    try:
        link = event.find_element(By.TAG_NAME, "a").get_attribute("href")
    except:
        link = None

    films.append({
        "title": title,
        "link": link,
        "showtime": showtime,
        "source": "Paradise Theatre"
    })

driver.quit()

# Print output
for film in films:
    print(f"🎬 {film['title']}")
    print(f"🕒 {film['showtime']}")
    print(f"🔗 {film['link']}")
    print("-" * 40)

# Save to JSON
with open("paradise_films.json", "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    json.dump(films, f, indent=2, ensure_ascii=False)

print("💾 Saved to paradise_films.json")

    "source": "Paradise Theatre"
  }
]

🧾 Full Script — paradise_scraper.py (for /coming-soon/)

python
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.service import Service
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.options import Options
import json
import time

CHROMEDRIVER_PATH = "D:/tools/chromedriver.exe"  # <-- Update this path

options = Options()
# options.add_argument("--headless")  # Enable this if you want headless
options.add_argument("--no-sandbox")
options.add_argument("--disable-dev-shm-usage")

service = Service(CHROMEDRIVER_PATH)
driver = webdriver.Chrome(service=service, options=options)

driver.get("https://paradiseonbloor.com/coming-soon/")
print("📄 Page loaded:", driver.title)

time.sleep(3)  # Let page load

films = []

# Each film is inside an article tag with class 'coming-soon-tile'
film_cards = driver.find_elements(By.CLASS_NAME, "coming-soon-tile")
print(f"✅ Found {len(film_cards)} films.\n")

for card in film_cards:
    try:
        title = card.find_element(By.CLASS_NAME, "coming-soon-title").text.strip()
    except:
        title = "Untitled"

    try:
        link = card.find_element(By.TAG_NAME, "a").get_attribute("href")
    except:
        link = None

    try:
        date = card.find_element(By.CLASS_NAME, "coming-soon-date").text.strip()
    except:
        date = "Unknown"

    films.append({
        "title": title,
        "link": link,
        "showtime": date,
        "source": "Paradise Theatre"
    })

driver.quit()

# Print results
for film in films:
    print(f"🎬 {film['title']}")
    print(f"🕒 {film['showtime']}")
    print(f"🔗 {film['link']}")
    print("-" * 40)

# Save to JSON
with open("paradise_films.json", "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    json.dump(films, f, indent=2, ensure_ascii=False)

print("💾 Saved to paradise_films.json")

✅ Updated Working Scraper for Paradise 🎉

🧾 Copy & Paste This New Version

python
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.service import Service
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.options import Options
import json
import time

CHROMEDRIVER_PATH = "D:/tools/chromedriver.exe"

options = Options()
# options.add_argument("--headless")
options.add_argument("--no-sandbox")
options.add_argument("--disable-dev-shm-usage")

service = Service(CHROMEDRIVER_PATH)
driver = webdriver.Chrome(service=service, options=options)

driver.get("https://paradiseonbloor.com/coming-soon/")
print("📄 Page loaded:", driver.title)
time.sleep(5)  # Wait for content to load

films = []

film_blocks = driver.find_elements(By.CLASS_NAME, "showtimes-description")
print(f"✅ Found {len(film_blocks)} film blocks")

for block in film_blocks:
    try:
        title_tag = block.find_element(By.CLASS_NAME, "show-title").find_element(By.TAG_NAME, "a")
        title = title_tag.text.strip()
        link = title_tag.get_attribute("href")
    except:
        title, link = "Untitled", None

    try:
        date_tag = block.find_element(By.CLASS_NAME, "selected-date")
        date = date_tag.text.strip().replace("\n", " ")
    except:
        date = "Unknown"

    try:
        time_tags = block.find_elements(By.CLASS_NAME, "showtime")
        times = [t.text.strip() for t in time_tags]
    except:
        times = []

    for t in times:
        films.append({
            "title": title,
            "link": link,
            "showtime": f"{date}, {t}",
            "source": "Paradise Theatre"
        })

driver.quit()

# Print result
for film in films:
    print(f"🎬 {film['title']}")
    print(f"🕒 {film['showtime']}")
    print(f"🔗 {film['link']}")
    print("-" * 40)

# Save to JSON
with open("paradise_films.json", "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    json.dump(films, f, indent=2, ensure_ascii=False)

print("💾 Saved to paradise_films.json")

✅ Next Step: Merge Both JSON Files & Generate a Combined HTML Calendar

We’ll:

  1. 📥 Load revue_films.json and paradise_films.json

  2. 🧩 Merge them into one list

  3. 🗂️ Sort and group by date

  4. 🌐 Generate all_films.html with theater names included

🧾 Here’s the Merging + HTML Generator Script

Save this as something like generate_all_films_html.py:

python
import json
from datetime import datetime
from collections import defaultdict

# === Load both JSON files ===
with open("revue_films.json", "r", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    revue = json.load(f)

with open("paradise_films.json", "r", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    paradise = json.load(f)

# === Combine them ===
all_films = revue + paradise

# === Parse + Group by date ===
calendar = defaultdict(list)

for film in all_films:
    raw = film["showtime"]
    try:
        dt = datetime.strptime(raw, "%a %b %d, %I:%M %p")
    except:
        try:
            dt = datetime.strptime(raw, "%a, %b %d, %I:%M %p")
        except:
            try:
                dt = datetime.strptime(raw, "%a %b %d",)  # fallback
            except:
                continue  # skip bad formats

    date_key = dt.strftime("%A, %B %d")
    time_str = dt.strftime("%I:%M %p")
    calendar[date_key].append({
        "title": film["title"],
        "link": film["link"],
        "time": time_str,
        "source": film.get("source", "Unknown")
    })

# === Sort by date ===
sorted_days = sorted(calendar.items(), key=lambda x: datetime.strptime(x[0], "%A, %B %d"))

# === Build HTML ===
html = """<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <title>Toronto Rep Cinema Calendar</title>
  <style>
    body { font-family: sans-serif; padding: 2rem; background: #f4f4f4; }
    h1 { font-size: 2rem; margin-bottom: 1rem; }
    h2 { margin-top: 2rem; border-bottom: 1px solid #ccc; padding-bottom: 0.3rem; }
    .film { margin: 0.5rem 0; }
    .time { font-weight: bold; margin-right: 0.5rem; }
    .source { font-style: italic; color: #555; margin-left: 0.5rem; }
    a { color: #333; text-decoration: none; }
  </style>
</head>
<body>
  <h1>🎬 Toronto Rep Cinema Calendar</h1>
"""

for date, films_on_day in sorted_days:
    html += f"<h2>{date}</h2>\n"
    for film in sorted(films_on_day, key=lambda f: f["time"]):
        html += (
            f"<div class='film'>"
            f"<span class='time'>{film['time']}</span>"
            f"<a href='{film['link']}' target='_blank'>{film['title']}</a>"
            f"<span class='source'>({film['source']})</span>"
            f"</div>\n"
        )

html += "</body></html>"

# === Save the file ===
with open("all_films.html", "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    f.write(html)

print("✅ Created all_films.html — open it in your browser!")

🎉 Output

You’ll get:

➡️ Open it to see a clean, combined calendar sorted by date, with times, links, and theater names.

✅ Plan for TIFF Bell Lightbox Scraper

TIFF’s site is built with Vue.js, which means:

  • Events are rendered dynamically after page load

  • Standard requests won’t work — we’ll use Selenium

  • We’ll wait for event cards to appear, then extract title, date/time, and detail link

🧾 Here’s the Full Working Selenium Script

python
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.service import Service
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.options import Options
import json
import time

CHROMEDRIVER_PATH = "D:/tools/chromedriver.exe"  # Update if needed

options = Options()
# options.add_argument("--headless")  # Enable headless if needed
options.add_argument("--no-sandbox")
options.add_argument("--disable-dev-shm-usage")

service = Service(CHROMEDRIVER_PATH)
driver = webdriver.Chrome(service=service, options=options)

driver.get("https://tiff.net/calendar")
print("📄 TIFF Calendar loaded:", driver.title)

# Let the page fully render (Vue.js needs extra time)
time.sleep(6)

# Save screenshot + HTML for debugging
driver.save_screenshot("tiff_debug.png")
with open("tiff_calendar_dump.html", "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    f.write(driver.page_source)

# Try to find event containers
event_cards = driver.find_elements(By.CLASS_NAME, "CalendarEventstyles__EventCard-sc-1kh1k5n-0")

print(f"✅ Found {len(event_cards)} event cards\n")

films = []

for card in event_cards:
    try:
        title = card.find_element(By.CLASS_NAME, "event-title").text.strip()
    except:
        title = "Untitled"

    try:
        link = card.find_element(By.TAG_NAME, "a").get_attribute("href")
    except:
        link = None

    try:
        datetime_block = card.find_element(By.CLASS_NAME, "CalendarEventstyles__StartTime-sc-1kh1k5n-2").text.strip()
    except:
        datetime_block = "Unknown"

    films.append({
        "title": title,
        "link": link,
        "showtime": datetime_block,
        "source": "TIFF Bell Lightbox"
    })

driver.quit()

# Output
for film in films:
    print(f"🎬 {film['title']}")
    print(f"🕒 {film['showtime']}")
    print(f"🔗 {film['link']}")
    print("-" * 40)

# Save to JSON
with open("tiff_films.json", "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    json.dump(films, f, indent=2, ensure_ascii=False)

print("💾 Saved TIFF films to tiff_films.json")

✅ Let's Update Your Scraper!

🧾 Updated TIFF Scraper

python
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.service import Service
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.options import Options
import json
import time

CHROMEDRIVER_PATH = "D:/tools/chromedriver.exe"  # Update if needed

options = Options()
# options.add_argument("--headless")  # Use headless if you like
options.add_argument("--no-sandbox")
options.add_argument("--disable-dev-shm-usage")

service = Service(CHROMEDRIVER_PATH)
driver = webdriver.Chrome(service=service, options=options)

driver.get("https://tiff.net/calendar")
print("📄 TIFF Calendar loaded:", driver.title)

time.sleep(6)  # Let Vue render everything

films = []

film_titles = driver.find_elements(By.CLASS_NAME, "style__cardTitle___3rkLd")
print(f"✅ Found {len(film_titles)} films")

for title_card in film_titles:
    try:
        title_tag = title_card.find_element(By.TAG_NAME, "a")
        title = title_tag.text.strip()
        event_link = title_tag.get_attribute("href")
        full_event_link = f"https://tiff.net{event_link}" if event_link.startswith("/") else event_link
    except:
        title = "Untitled"
        full_event_link = None

    # Try to find the nearest time and ticket link within the parent
    try:
        parent = title_card.find_element(By.XPATH, "..")  # Go up one level
        screening_time = parent.find_element(By.CLASS_NAME, "style__screeningDisplayTime___2VUn1").text.strip()
        ticket_link = parent.find_element(By.CLASS_NAME, "style__screeningButtonLink___kUNSA").get_attribute("href")
    except:
        screening_time = "Unknown"
        ticket_link = full_event_link

    films.append({
        "title": title,
        "link": ticket_link,
        "showtime": screening_time,
        "source": "TIFF Bell Lightbox"
    })

driver.quit()

# Print and save
for film in films:
    print(f"🎬 {film['title']}")
    print(f"🕒 {film['showtime']}")
    print(f"🔗 {film['link']}")
    print("-" * 40)

with open("tiff_films.json", "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    json.dump(films, f, indent=2, ensure_ascii=False)

print("💾 Saved TIFF films to tiff_films.json")

  "title": "Bob Trevino Likes It",
  "link": "https://am.ticketmaster.com/tiff/...",
  "showtime": "8:45pm",
  "source": "TIFF Bell Lightbox"
}

Perfect! Here's your fully updated script that:

✅ Merges data from:

  • revue_films.json

  • paradise_films.json

  • tiff_films.json

✅ Sorts by date + time
✅ Displays title, time, theater source, and link
✅ Outputs a clean HTML file: all_films.html

🧾 Full Merging & HTML Generator Script

python
import json
from datetime import datetime
from collections import defaultdict

# === Load JSON files ===
def load_json(path):
    with open(path, "r", encoding="utf-8") as f:
        return json.load(f)

revue = load_json("revue_films.json")
paradise = load_json("paradise_films.json")
tiff = load_json("tiff_films.json")

# === Combine and prepare ===
all_films = revue + paradise + tiff

# === Normalize and group by date ===
calendar = defaultdict(list)

for film in all_films:
    raw = film["showtime"]
    title = film["title"]
    link = film["link"]
    source = film.get("source", "Unknown")

    # Try parsing the showtime into a datetime
    dt = None
    for fmt in [
        "%a %b %d, %I:%M %p",
        "%a, %b %d, %I:%M %p",
        "%a %b %d",
        "%b %d, %I:%M %p",
        "%I:%M %p",  # fallback if we only get time (e.g., TIFF)
    ]:
        try:
            dt = datetime.strptime(raw, fmt)
            break
        except:
            continue

    # If we can't parse a date, default to 'Unknown Date'
    date_key = dt.strftime("%A, %B %d") if dt else "Unknown Date"
    time_str = dt.strftime("%I:%M %p") if dt else raw

    calendar[date_key].append({
        "title": title,
        "link": link,
        "time": time_str,
        "source": source
    })

# === Sort dates ===
sorted_days = sorted(
    calendar.items(),
    key=lambda x: datetime.strptime(x[0], "%A, %B %d") if x[0] != "Unknown Date" else datetime.max
)

# === Generate HTML ===
html = """<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <title>Toronto Rep Cinema Calendar</title>
  <style>
    body { font-family: sans-serif; padding: 2rem; background: #f7f7f7; color: #333; }
    h1 { font-size: 2rem; margin-bottom: 1rem; }
    h2 { margin-top: 2rem; border-bottom: 1px solid #ccc; padding-bottom: 0.3rem; }
    .film { margin: 0.5rem 0; }
    .time { font-weight: bold; margin-right: 0.5rem; }
    .source { font-style: italic; color: #888; margin-left: 0.5rem; }
    a { color: #333; text-decoration: none; }
    a:hover { text-decoration: underline; }
  </style>
</head>
<body>
  <h1>🎬 Toronto Rep Cinema Calendar</h1>
"""

for date, films_on_day in sorted_days:
    html += f"<h2>{date}</h2>\n"
    for film in sorted(films_on_day, key=lambda f: f["time"]):
        html += (
            f"<div class='film'>"
            f"<span class='time'>{film['time']}</span>"
            f"<a href='{film['link']}' target='_blank'>{film['title']}</a>"
            f"<span class='source'>({film['source']})</span>"
            f"</div>\n"
        )

html += "</body></html>"

# === Save to HTML file ===
with open("all_films.html", "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    f.write(html)

print("✅ Created all_films.html — open it in your browser!")

✅ To Run:

  1. Make sure all 3 JSONs (revue_films.json, paradise_films.json, tiff_films.json) exist

  2. Run this script: python generate_all_films_html.py

  3. Open the file: all_films.html

json

✅ 2 Easy Options to Solve This

🔁 Option 1: Add the current date as a placeholder for TIFF films

If you're scraping today’s listings only, we can attach today’s date to each TIFF showtime.

🧠 Option 2: Actually extract the date per event (if it’s available somewhere on the page or in grouped headers)

Let’s go with Option 1 now to unblock you and get the calendar working.

🧾 Update to Patch TIFF Entries with Today's Date

Add this right after loading all JSON files in your merge script:

python
from datetime import datetime, date

# Patch TIFF entries to add today's date
today_str = date.today().strftime("%a %b %d")  # e.g., 'Mon Apr 08'

for film in tiff:
    if len(film["showtime"]) <= 8:  # e.g., "8:45pm"
        film["showtime"] = f"{today_str}, {film['showtime']}"

This turns:

json
"showtime": "8:45pm"

into:

json
"showtime": "Mon Apr 08, 8:45pm"

✅ Which now works with the rest of your datetime formatting.

Inside each <li>, we’ll find:

✅ Updated TIFF Scraper: Now Includes Actual Dates

python
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.service import Service
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.options import Options
import json
import time

CHROMEDRIVER_PATH = "D:/tools/chromedriver.exe"  # Update if needed

options = Options()
# options.add_argument("--headless")
options.add_argument("--no-sandbox")
options.add_argument("--disable-dev-shm-usage")

service = Service(CHROMEDRIVER_PATH)
driver = webdriver.Chrome(service=service, options=options)

driver.get("https://tiff.net/calendar")
print("📄 TIFF Calendar loaded:", driver.title)

time.sleep(6)  # Let Vue render

films = []

# Get all daily sections
day_sections = driver.find_elements(By.CLASS_NAME, "calendar-list-item")

print(f"✅ Found {len(day_sections)} calendar sections")

for section in day_sections:
    try:
        # Grab date from header like: <h2>Today Apr 8</h2>
        date_header = section.find_element(By.CLASS_NAME, "style__date___312bI").text.strip()
        # Normalize date string (e.g., remove "Today" if it's present)
        if "Today" in date_header or "Tomorrow" in date_header:
            date_parts = date_header.split()
            if len(date_parts) > 1:
                date_str = " ".join(date_parts[1:])
            else:
                date_str = date_header
        else:
            date_str = date_header
    except:
        date_str = "Unknown Date"

    # Inside the section, find all films
    films_in_section = section.find_elements(By.CLASS_NAME, "style__cardTitle___3rkLd")

    for title_card in films_in_section:
        try:
            title_tag = title_card.find_element(By.TAG_NAME, "a")
            title = title_tag.text.strip()
            if "Film Reference Library" in title:
                continue  # Skip non-screening entries
            event_link = title_tag.get_attribute("href")
            full_event_link = f"https://tiff.net{event_link}" if event_link.startswith("/") else event_link
        except:
            title = "Untitled"
            full_event_link = None

        try:
            parent = title_card.find_element(By.XPATH, "..")
            screening_time = parent.find_element(By.CLASS_NAME, "style__screeningDisplayTime___2VUn1").text.strip()
            ticket_link = parent.find_element(By.CLASS_NAME, "style__screeningButtonLink___kUNSA").get_attribute("href")
        except:
            screening_time = "Unknown"
            ticket_link = full_event_link

        full_showtime = f"{date_str}, {screening_time}"
        films.append({
            "title": title,
            "link": ticket_link,
            "showtime": full_showtime,
            "source": "TIFF Bell Lightbox"
        })

driver.quit()

# Print results
for film in films:
    print(f"🎬 {film['title']}")
    print(f"🕒 {film['showtime']}")
    print(f"🔗 {film['link']}")
    print("-" * 40)

# Save to JSON
with open("tiff_films.json", "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    json.dump(films, f, indent=2, ensure_ascii=False)

print("💾 Saved TIFF films to tiff_films.json")

Which is:

(e.g., "Apr 08, 8:45pm")

Notice:

  • No day-of-week (%a)

    "%a %b %d",
    "%b %d, %I:%M %p",

]:

🛠 Add TIFF’s format:

python
    "%b %d, %I:%M%p",         # <-- no space before pm
    "%b %d, %I:%M %p",        # <-- space before pm (the likely one)

Make sure this one is included near the top:

python
"%b %d, %I:%M %p",

So the full list becomes:

python
for fmt in [
    "%b %d, %I:%M %p",         # TIFF format: Apr 8, 8:45 PM
    "%a %b %d, %I:%M %p",
    "%a, %b %d, %I:%M %p",
    "%a %b %d",
    "%I:%M %p"
]:

If your TIFF JSON now contains entries like:

json
"showtime": "Apr 8, 8:45pm"

…but they still show up under "Unknown Date" in the merged calendar, then the likely issues are:

✅ Diagnosis

  1. The merge script's date parsing is failing to match TIFF's format

  2. TIFF's format may have a lowercase “pm”, and your format string expects uppercase (%p)

  3. You may have leading/trailing spaces or inconsistent spacing

🧪 Let's Inspect an Exact Example

Can you copy and paste the exact showtime value of one TIFF entry from your tiff_films.json?

Example:

json
"showtime": "Apr 8, 8:45pm"

If it really is that — here's the fix:

✅ Guaranteed Fix for the Merge Script

🔄 Replace the date parsing loop in your merge script with:

python
from dateutil import parser

for film in all_films:
    raw = film["showtime"]
    title = film["title"]
    link = film["link"]
    source = film.get("source", "Unknown")

    try:
        dt = parser.parse(raw)
        date_key = dt.strftime("%A, %B %d")
        time_str = dt.strftime("%I:%M %p")
    except:
        date_key = "Unknown Date"
        time_str = raw  # fallback

    calendar[date_key].append({
        "title": title,
        "link": link,
        "time": time_str,
        "source": source
    })

✅ Why This Works

Using dateutil.parser.parse() automatically handles:

  • Missing day-of-week

  • Weird spacing

  • Case-insensitive AM/PM

  • Mixed formats from different theaters

plaintext

✅ Fix the Merge Script’s Parsing

In your merge script, update the loop that tries to parse dates to this:

python
for fmt in [
    "%A %B %d, %I:%M %p",     # TIFF format: Tuesday May 13, 7:00pm
    "%b %d, %I:%M %p",        # fallback for short formats
    "%a %b %d, %I:%M %p",
    "%a, %b %d, %I:%M %p",
    "%a %b %d",
    "%I:%M %p"
]:

Put the %A %B %d, %I:%M %p format at the top — this exactly matches "Tuesday May 13, 7:00pm".

✅ Step-by-Step: Switching to dateutil for Date Parsing

🧱 Step 1: Install the dateutil Package

Open your terminal and run:

bash
pip install python-dateutil

That gives you the powerful parser.parse() function.

🧾 Step 2: Update Your Merge Script

Here’s the full working version of the updated merge script that uses dateutil.

Replace your old merge logic with this:

python
import json
from datetime import datetime
from collections import defaultdict
from dateutil import parser

# === Load JSON files ===
def load_json(path):
    with open(path, "r", encoding="utf-8") as f:
        return json.load(f)

revue = load_json("revue_films.json")
paradise = load_json("paradise_films.json")
tiff = load_json("tiff_films.json")

# === Combine all films ===
all_films = revue + paradise + tiff

# === Group films by date ===
calendar = defaultdict(list)

for film in all_films:
    raw = film["showtime"]
    title = film["title"]
    link = film["link"]
    source = film.get("source", "Unknown")

    try:
        dt = parser.parse(raw)
        date_key = dt.strftime("%A, %B %d")  # e.g., "Tuesday, May 13"
        time_str = dt.strftime("%I:%M %p")
    except:
        date_key = "Unknown Date"
        time_str = raw  # fallback

    calendar[date_key].append({
        "title": title,
        "link": link,
        "time": time_str,
        "source": source
    })

# === Sort dates ===
sorted_days = sorted(
    calendar.items(),
    key=lambda x: datetime.strptime(x[0], "%A, %B %d") if x[0] != "Unknown Date" else datetime.max
)

# === Build HTML ===
html = """<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <title>Toronto Rep Cinema Calendar</title>
  <style>
    body { font-family: sans-serif; padding: 2rem; background: #f7f7f7; color: #333; }
    h1 { font-size: 2rem; margin-bottom: 1rem; }
    h2 { margin-top: 2rem; border-bottom: 1px solid #ccc; padding-bottom: 0.3rem; }
    .film { margin: 0.5rem 0; }
    .time { font-weight: bold; margin-right: 0.5rem; }
    .source { font-style: italic; color: #888; margin-left: 0.5rem; }
    a { color: #333; text-decoration: none; }
    a:hover { text-decoration: underline; }
  </style>
</head>
<body>
  <h1>🎬 Toronto Rep Cinema Calendar</h1>
"""

for date, films_on_day in sorted_days:
    html += f"<h2>{date}</h2>\n"
    for film in sorted(films_on_day, key=lambda f: f["time"]):
        html += (
            f"<div class='film'>"
            f"<span class='time'>{film['time']}</span>"
            f"<a href='{film['link']}' target='_blank'>{film['title']}</a>"
            f"<span class='source'>({film['source']})</span>"
            f"</div>\n"
        )

html += "</body></html>"

# === Save HTML ===
with open("all_films.html", "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    f.write(html)

print("✅ Created all_films.html — open it in your browser!")

💡 Why This Works

dateutil.parser.parse() automatically understands:

  • "Tuesday May 13, 7:00pm"

  • "Apr 9, 6:00 PM"

  • "Fri Apr 12, 9:30pm"

  • And nearly any other reasonable date format from different theaters

No need for complex format matching — it's future-proof.

  • Deploy this as a simple web app!

✅ Updated HTML Generator with Dropdown Filter

Paste this into your merge script to replace your old HTML builder block:

python
# === Build HTML with dropdown filter ===
html = """<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <title>Toronto Rep Cinema Calendar</title>
  <style>
    body { font-family: sans-serif; padding: 2rem; background: #f7f7f7; color: #333; }
    h1 { font-size: 2rem; margin-bottom: 1rem; }
    h2 { margin-top: 2rem; border-bottom: 1px solid #ccc; padding-bottom: 0.3rem; }
    .film { margin: 0.5rem 0; }
    .time { font-weight: bold; margin-right: 0.5rem; }
    .source { font-style: italic; color: #888; margin-left: 0.5rem; }
    a { color: #333; text-decoration: none; }
    a:hover { text-decoration: underline; }
    select { padding: 0.3rem; font-size: 1rem; margin-bottom: 1.5rem; }
  </style>
  <script>
    function filterTheater(source) {
      const allFilms = document.querySelectorAll('.film');
      allFilms.forEach(film => {
        const theater = film.getAttribute('data-source');
        film.style.display = (source === 'all' || source === theater) ? 'block' : 'none';
      });
    }
  </script>
</head>
<body>
  <h1>🎬 Toronto Rep Cinema Calendar</h1>
  <label for="filter">🎭 Filter by Theater:</label>
  <select id="filter" onchange="filterTheater(this.value)">
    <option value="all">All Theaters</option>
    <option value="Revue Cinema">Revue Cinema</option>
    <option value="Paradise Theatre">Paradise Theatre</option>
    <option value="TIFF Bell Lightbox">TIFF Bell Lightbox</option>
  </select>
"""

# Add content grouped by date
for date, films_on_day in sorted_days:
    html += f"<h2>{date}</h2>\n"
    for film in sorted(films_on_day, key=lambda f: f["time"]):
        source = film['source']
        html += (
            f"<div class='film' data-source='{source}'>"
            f"<span class='time'>{film['time']}</span>"
            f"<a href='{film['link']}' target='_blank'>{film['title']}</a>"
            f"<span class='source'>({source})</span>"
            f"</div>\n"
        )

html += "</body></html>"

✅ How It Works

  • Adds a <select> dropdown

  • Each .film entry includes a data-source attribute (like "TIFF Bell Lightbox")

  • JavaScript hides/shows .film divs based on the selected theater

💡 Tip

You can style the dropdown or even swap it for tabs later. Want me to help turn it into a tabbed layout with smooth transitions next?

Otherwise — run your updated script, open all_films.html, and enjoy your clean, filterable calendar!

You said:
The theater names all seem to appear white
ChatGPT said:

Ah — good call! The issue is with how CSS interprets class names that contain spaces (like "TIFF Bell Lightbox"). In your HTML, you have:

html
<span class='theater-label TIFF Bell Lightbox'>TIFF Bell Lightbox</span>

…but in your CSS, we used this to target it:

css
.TIFF\ Bell\ Lightbox { background-color: #ef4444; }

That only works if the browser properly escapes the class name. But it’s much cleaner and more reliable to use class-safe CSS identifiers like:

nginx
tiff
revue
paradise

✅ Step-by-Step Fix: Use Clean CSS Class Names

🔁 Step 1: Replace Theater Class Names with IDs

Update the theater label generator in your Python code like this:

python
# Map readable names to CSS-safe class names
theater_classes = {
    "Revue Cinema": "revue",
    "Paradise Theatre": "paradise",
    "TIFF Bell Lightbox": "tiff"
}

...

css_class = theater_classes.get(source, "default")
html += (
    f"<div class='film' data-source='{source}'>"
    f"<span class='time'>{film['time']}</span>"
    f"<a href='{film['link']}' target='_blank'>{film['title']}</a>"
    f"<span class='theater-label {css_class}'>{source}</span>"
    f"</div>\n"
)

🔁 Step 2: Update Your CSS to Use These Class Names

Replace the original CSS block for theater colors with:

css
.theater-label.revue    { background-color: #3b82f6; }  /* Blue */
.theater-label.paradise { background-color: #10b981; }  /* Green */
.theater-label.tiff     { background-color: #ef4444; }  /* Red */

html

🧾 Full Copy-and-Paste Script

python
import json
from datetime import datetime
from collections import defaultdict
from dateutil import parser

# === Load JSON files ===
def load_json(path):
    with open(path, "r", encoding="utf-8") as f:
        return json.load(f)

revue = load_json("revue_films.json")
paradise = load_json("paradise_films.json")
tiff = load_json("tiff_films.json")

# === Combine and prepare ===
all_films = revue + paradise + tiff
calendar = defaultdict(list)

# === Parse and group by date ===
for film in all_films:
    raw = film["showtime"]
    title = film["title"]
    link = film["link"]
    source = film.get("source", "Unknown")

    try:
        dt = parser.parse(raw)
        date_key = dt.strftime("%A, %B %d")
        time_str = dt.strftime("%I:%M %p")
    except:
        date_key = "Unknown Date"
        time_str = raw

    calendar[date_key].append({
        "title": title,
        "link": link,
        "time": time_str,
        "source": source
    })

# === Sort calendar by date ===
sorted_days = sorted(
    calendar.items(),
    key=lambda x: datetime.strptime(x[0], "%A, %B %d") if x[0] != "Unknown Date" else datetime.max
)

# === Map sources to safe CSS classes ===
theater_classes = {
    "Revue Cinema": "revue",
    "Paradise Theatre": "paradise",
    "TIFF Bell Lightbox": "tiff"
}

# === Build HTML ===
html = """<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <title>Toronto Rep Cinema Calendar</title>
  <style>
    body { font-family: sans-serif; padding: 2rem; background: #f7f7f7; color: #333; }
    h1 { font-size: 2rem; margin-bottom: 1rem; }
    h2 { margin-top: 2rem; border-bottom: 1px solid #ccc; padding-bottom: 0.3rem; }
    .film { margin: 0.5rem 0; }
    .time { font-weight: bold; margin-right: 0.5rem; }
    .theater-label {
      display: inline-block;
      padding: 0.2rem 0.5rem;
      border-radius: 0.3rem;
      font-size: 0.85rem;
      font-weight: bold;
      margin-left: 0.5rem;
      color: white;
    }
    .theater-label.revue    { background-color: #3b82f6; }  /* Blue */
    .theater-label.paradise { background-color: #10b981; }  /* Green */
    .theater-label.tiff     { background-color: #ef4444; }  /* Red */
    a { color: #333; text-decoration: none; }
    a:hover { text-decoration: underline; }
    select { padding: 0.3rem; font-size: 1rem; margin-bottom: 1.5rem; }
  </style>
  <script>
    function filterTheater(source) {
      const allFilms = document.querySelectorAll('.film');
      allFilms.forEach(film => {
        const theater = film.getAttribute('data-source');
        film.style.display = (source === 'all' || source === theater) ? 'block' : 'none';
      });
    }
  </script>
</head>
<body>
  <h1>🎬 Toronto Rep Cinema Calendar</h1>
  <label for="filter">🎭 Filter by Theater:</label>
  <select id="filter" onchange="filterTheater(this.value)">
    <option value="all">All Theaters</option>
    <option value="Revue Cinema">Revue Cinema</option>
    <option value="Paradise Theatre">Paradise Theatre</option>
    <option value="TIFF Bell Lightbox">TIFF Bell Lightbox</option>
  </select>
"""

# === Add content grouped by date ===
for date, films_on_day in sorted_days:
    html += f"<h2>{date}</h2>\n"
    for film in sorted(films_on_day, key=lambda f: f["time"]):
        source = film["source"]
        css_class = theater_classes.get(source, "default")
        html += (
            f"<div class='film' data-source='{source}'>"
            f"<span class='time'>{film['time']}</span>"
            f"<a href='{film['link']}' target='_blank'>{film['title']}</a>"
            f"<span class='theater-label {css_class}'>{source}</span>"
            f"</div>\n"
        )

html += "</body></html>"

# === Save file ===
with open("all_films.html", "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    f.write(html)

print("✅ Created all_films.html — open it in your browser!")

🧾 Full Updated HTML Generator With Tabs

Replace your existing HTML-building section with this full script:

python
import json
from datetime import datetime
from collections import defaultdict
from dateutil import parser

# === Load JSON files ===
def load_json(path):
    with open(path, "r", encoding="utf-8") as f:
        return json.load(f)

revue = load_json("revue_films.json")
paradise = load_json("paradise_films.json")
tiff = load_json("tiff_films.json")

# === Combine all ===
all_films = revue + paradise + tiff
calendar = defaultdict(list)

for film in all_films:
    raw = film["showtime"]
    title = film["title"]
    link = film["link"]
    source = film.get("source", "Unknown")

    try:
        dt = parser.parse(raw)
        date_key = dt.strftime("%A, %B %d")
        time_str = dt.strftime("%I:%M %p")
    except:
        date_key = "Unknown Date"
        time_str = raw

    calendar[date_key].append({
        "title": title,
        "link": link,
        "time": time_str,
        "source": source
    })

# === Sort by date ===
sorted_days = sorted(
    calendar.items(),
    key=lambda x: datetime.strptime(x[0], "%A, %B %d") if x[0] != "Unknown Date" else datetime.max
)

# === Map sources to CSS class names
theater_classes = {
    "Revue Cinema": "revue",
    "Paradise Theatre": "paradise",
    "TIFF Bell Lightbox": "tiff"
}

# === Build HTML ===
html = """<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <title>Toronto Rep Cinema Calendar</title>
  <style>
    body { font-family: sans-serif; padding: 2rem; background: #f7f7f7; color: #333; }
    h1 { font-size: 2rem; margin-bottom: 1rem; }
    h2 { margin-top: 2rem; border-bottom: 1px solid #ccc; padding-bottom: 0.3rem; }
    .film { margin: 0.5rem 0; }
    .time { font-weight: bold; margin-right: 0.5rem; }
    .theater-label {
      display: inline-block;
      padding: 0.2rem 0.5rem;
      border-radius: 0.3rem;
      font-size: 0.85rem;
      font-weight: bold;
      margin-left: 0.5rem;
      color: white;
    }
    .theater-label.revue    { background-color: #3b82f6; }
    .theater-label.paradise { background-color: #10b981; }
    .theater-label.tiff     { background-color: #ef4444; }
    a { color: #333; text-decoration: none; }
    a:hover { text-decoration: underline; }

    .tabs {
      display: flex;
      gap: 1rem;
      margin-bottom: 1.5rem;
    }
    .tab {
      padding: 0.5rem 1rem;
      background: #eee;
      border-radius: 0.3rem;
      cursor: pointer;
      font-weight: bold;
    }
    .tab.active {
      background: #333;
      color: white;
    }
    .tab-content {
      display: none;
    }
    .tab-content.active {
      display: block;
    }
  </style>
  <script>
    function showTab(tabId) {
      const tabs = document.querySelectorAll('.tab');
      const contents = document.querySelectorAll('.tab-content');

      tabs.forEach(tab => tab.classList.remove('active'));
      contents.forEach(content => content.classList.remove('active'));

      document.getElementById(tabId).classList.add('active');
      document.querySelector(`[data-tab="${tabId}"]`).classList.add('active');
    }

    window.onload = function() {
      showTab('all'); // default
    }
  </script>
</head>
<body>
  <h1>🎬 Toronto Rep Cinema Calendar</h1>

  <div class="tabs">
    <div class="tab active" data-tab="all" onclick="showTab('all')">All Theaters</div>
    <div class="tab" data-tab="revue" onclick="showTab('revue')">Revue Cinema</div>
    <div class="tab" data-tab="paradise" onclick="showTab('paradise')">Paradise Theatre</div>
    <div class="tab" data-tab="tiff" onclick="showTab('tiff')">TIFF Bell Lightbox</div>
  </div>
"""

# === Create separate content for each tab ===
tab_sources = ["all", "Revue Cinema", "Paradise Theatre", "TIFF Bell Lightbox"]

for tab in tab_sources:
    tab_id = tab.lower().split()[0] if tab != "all" else "all"
    html += f'<div class="tab-content" id="{tab_id}">\n'

    for date, films_on_day in sorted_days:
        films_for_tab = films_on_day if tab == "all" else [f for f in films_on_day if f["source"] == tab]
        if not films_for_tab:
            continue

        html += f"<h2>{date}</h2>\n"
        for film in sorted(films_for_tab, key=lambda f: f["time"]):
            source = film["source"]
            css_class = theater_classes.get(source, "default")
            html += (
                f"<div class='film'>"
                f"<span class='time'>{film['time']}</span>"
                f"<a href='{film['link']}' target='_blank'>{film['title']}</a>"
                f"<span class='theater-label {css_class}'>{source}</span>"
                f"</div>\n"
            )

    html += "</div>\n"

html += "</body></html>"

# === Save to HTML ===
with open("all_films.html", "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    f.write(html)

print("✅ Created all_films.html with tabs — open it in your browser!")

✅ Copy-and-Paste: generate_calendar_grid.py

python
import json
from datetime import datetime
from collections import defaultdict
from dateutil import parser

# === Load JSON files ===
def load_json(path):
    with open(path, "r", encoding="utf-8") as f:
        return json.load(f)

revue = load_json("revue_films.json")
paradise = load_json("paradise_films.json")
tiff = load_json("tiff_films.json")

# === Combine and parse ===
all_films = revue + paradise + tiff
date_map = defaultdict(list)
months = set()

for film in all_films:
    raw = film["showtime"]
    try:
        dt = parser.parse(raw)
    except:
        continue

    date_key = dt.strftime("%Y-%m-%d")
    readable_date = dt.strftime("%A, %B %d")
    month_key = dt.strftime("%B %Y")
    time_str = dt.strftime("%I:%M %p")

    months.add(month_key)
    date_map[date_key].append({
        "readable": readable_date,
        "time": time_str,
        "title": film["title"],
        "link": film["link"],
        "source": film.get("source", "Unknown"),
        "month": month_key
    })

# === Sort data ===
sorted_dates = sorted(date_map.keys())
sorted_months = sorted(months, key=lambda m: datetime.strptime(m, "%B %Y"))

# === CSS-safe classes ===
theater_classes = {
    "Revue Cinema": "revue",
    "Paradise Theatre": "paradise",
    "TIFF Bell Lightbox": "tiff"
}

# === Build HTML ===
html = """<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <title>Rep Cinema Calendar</title>
  <style>
    body { font-family: sans-serif; padding: 2rem; background: #f9f9f9; color: #333; }
    h1 { font-size: 2rem; margin-bottom: 2rem; }
    h2 { font-size: 1.5rem; margin-top: 2rem; margin-bottom: 1rem; border-bottom: 1px solid #ccc; padding-bottom: 0.3rem; }
    .grid { display: grid; grid-template-columns: repeat(auto-fill, minmax(250px, 1fr)); gap: 1rem; }
    .day-box {
      background: white;
      border: 1px solid #ddd;
      border-radius: 0.5rem;
      padding: 1rem;
      box-shadow: 0 1px 4px rgba(0,0,0,0.05);
    }
    .day-box h3 {
      margin-top: 0;
      font-size: 1rem;
      color: #555;
    }
    .film {
      margin: 0.5rem 0;
      line-height: 1.4;
    }
    .time { font-weight: bold; margin-right: 0.5rem; }
    .label {
      display: inline-block;
      padding: 0.2rem 0.5rem;
      border-radius: 0.3rem;
      font-size: 0.8rem;
      font-weight: bold;
      color: white;
    }
    .revue { background-color: #3b82f6; }
    .paradise { background-color: #10b981; }
    .tiff { background-color: #ef4444; }
    a { color: #333; text-decoration: none; }
    a:hover { text-decoration: underline; }
  </style>
</head>
<body>
  <h1>🎬 Toronto Rep Cinema Calendar</h1>
"""

# === Generate each month section ===
for month in sorted_months:
    html += f"<h2>{month}</h2>\n"
    html += "<div class='grid'>\n"

    for date in sorted_dates:
        films = date_map[date]
        if not films or films[0]["month"] != month:
            continue

        html += f"<div class='day-box'>"
        html += f"<h3>{films[0]['readable']}</h3>"
        for film in sorted(films, key=lambda x: x["time"]):
            css = theater_classes.get(film["source"], "default")
            html += (
                f"<div class='film'>"
                f"<span class='time'>{film['time']}</span>"
                f"<a href='{film['link']}' target='_blank'>{film['title']}</a><br>"
                f"<span class='label {css}'>{film['source']}</span>"
                f"</div>"
            )
        html += "</div>\n"

    html += "</div>\n"

html += "</body></html>"

# === Save HTML ===
with open("calendar_grid.html", "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    f.write(html)

print("✅ Created calendar_grid.html — open it in your browser!")

✅ To Use:

  2. Make sure revue_films.json, paradise_films.json, tiff_films.json are up to date

      });

      // Hide entire day-boxes if all films inside are hidden
      const boxes = document.querySelectorAll('.day-box');
      boxes.forEach(box => {
        const visible = box.querySelectorAll('.film:not([style*="display: none"])').length > 0;
        box.style.display = visible ? 'block' : 'none';
      });
    }

</head>

  </select>

from datetime import datetime
from collections import defaultdict
from dateutil import parser

# === Load JSON files ===
def load_json(path):
    with open(path, "r", encoding="utf-8") as f:
        return json.load(f)

revue = load_json("revue_films.json")
paradise = load_json("paradise_films.json")

# === Combine and parse ===
all_films = revue + paradise + tiff
date_map = defaultdict(list)
months = set()

for film in all_films:
    raw = film["showtime"]
    try:
        dt = parser.parse(raw)
    except:

    date_key = dt.strftime("%Y-%m-%d")
    readable_date = dt.strftime("%A, %B %d")

      margin-bottom: 1rem;
      font-size: 1rem;
      margin-right: 0.5rem;
    }
    .hidden { display: none; }
  </style>
  <script>
    function filterTheater(theater) {
      document.querySelectorAll('.film').forEach(film => {
        const source = film.getAttribute('data-source');
        film.style.display = (theater === 'all' || source === theater) ? 'block' : 'none';
      });

      document.querySelectorAll('.day-box, .list-day').forEach(day => {
        const visible = day.querySelectorAll('.film:not([style*="display: none"])').length > 0;
        day.style.display = visible ? 'block' : 'none';
      });
    }

    function toggleView(viewId) {
      document.getElementById('grid-view').classList.add('hidden');
      document.getElementById('list-view').classList.add('hidden');
      document.getElementById(viewId).classList.remove('hidden');
    }

    window.onload = function() {
      toggleView('grid-view');
    }
  </script>
</head>
<body>
  <h1>🎬 Toronto Rep Cinema Calendar</h1>
  <div class="controls">
    <label for="filter">🎭 Filter by Theater:</label>
    <select id="filter" onchange="filterTheater(this.value)">
      <option value="all">All Theaters</option>
      <option value="Revue Cinema">Revue Cinema</option>
      <option value="Paradise Theatre">Paradise Theatre</option>
      <option value="TIFF Bell Lightbox">TIFF Bell Lightbox</option>
    </select>

    <div class="toggle-btns">
      <button onclick="toggleView('grid-view')">🗓️ Grid View</button>
      <button onclick="toggleView('list-view')">📃 List View</button>
    </div>
  </div>
"""

# === Grid view ===
html += "<div id='grid-view'>\n"
for month in sorted_months:
    html += f"<h2>{month}</h2>\n"
    html += "<div class='grid'>\n"
    for date in sorted_dates:
        films = date_map[date]
        if not films or films[0]["month"] != month:
            continue
        html += f"<div class='day-box'>"
        html += f"<h3>{films[0]['readable']}</h3>"
        for film in sorted(films, key=lambda x: x["time"]):
            css = theater_classes.get(film["source"], "default")
            html += (
                f"<div class='film' data-source='{film['source']}'>"
                f"<span class='time'>{film['time']}</span>"
                f"<a href='{film['link']}' target='_blank'>{film['title']}</a><br>"
                f"<span class='label {css}'>{film['source']}</span>"
                f"</div>"
            )
        html += "</div>\n"
    html += "</div>\n"
html += "</div>\n"

# === List view ===
html += "<div id='list-view' class='hidden'>\n"
for date in sorted_dates:
    films = date_map[date]
    html += f"<div class='list-day'><h2>{films[0]['readable']}</h2>\n"
    for film in sorted(films, key=lambda x: x["time"]):
        css = theater_classes.get(film["source"], "default")
        html += (
            f"<div class='film' data-source='{film['source']}'>"
            f"<span class='time'>{film['time']}</span>"
            f"<a href='{film['link']}' target='_blank'>{film['title']}</a>"
            f"<span class='label {css}'>{film['source']}</span>"
            f"</div>\n"
        )
    html += "</div>\n"
html += "</div>\n"

# === Close and save ===
html += "</body></html>"

with open("calendar_grid.html", "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    f.write(html)

print("✅ Created calendar_grid.html with grid + list toggle and filter — open it in your browser!")

✅ What’s Included

  • 🎭 Theater dropdown filter (works across views)

  • 🔄 Toggle buttons for Grid View and List View

  • 🎨 Color-coded theater labels

  • 📅 Month grouping and responsive layout

Looking at the ouput again it seems like there are show times missing. As an example there are two showings The Ballad of Wallis Island on the 8th and only one show time on the calendar we created
ChatGPT said:

Good catch — that kind of detail is exactly what we want to get right. Let’s debug this step by step to figure out why one of the showtimes is missing for The Ballad of Wallis Island on April 8th.

🔍 Here's What Might Be Happening

✅ Possibility 1: The Scraper Is Only Grabbing One Showtime Per Film

Many theaters (like TIFF or Paradise) have:

  • Multiple showtimes per day for the same film

  • But your current scraper might only grab the first time per film

If the structure is like:

html
<h3>Film Title</h3>
<span>7:00pm</span>
<span>9:30pm</span>

Your code might only be extracting the first <span> it finds.

✅ Possibility 2: Multiple Showtimes Are on Separate Cards (But Have Same Title)

Some sites list:

  • The same film multiple times as separate blocks/cards (e.g. one per showtime)

  • Your script might overwrite or skip entries with identical titles or dates

✅ Here’s What to Check (in your scraper)

Pick the theater where this happened — likely Paradise Theatre — and look at this section in your scrape_paradise.py:

python
# Example
films.append({
    "title": title,
    "link": link,
    "showtime": showtime,
    "source": "Paradise Theatre"
})

If there are multiple <li> or <span> times per title:

You need to loop over each showtime instead of grabbing just one.

✅ Fix Pattern

🔁 Instead of:

python
showtime = film.find_element(...).text
films.append({...})

Use:

python
showtimes = film.find_elements(By.CLASS_NAME, "showtime")  # or whatever the class is
for st in showtimes:
    time = st.text.strip()
    films.append({
        "title": title,
        "link": link,
        "showtime": f"{date_str}, {time}",
        "source": "Paradise Theatre"
    })

ChatGPT said:

Perfect — thanks! So the issue is in the TIFF scraper, which currently only pulls one showtime per film, even when there are multiple screenings on the same day (like The Ballad of Wallis Island).

Let's fix that. 🔧

✅ Problem Recap

TIFF’s calendar structure shows multiple screening times per film, like:

html
<h3 class="style__cardTitle___...">
  <a href="/events/the-ballad-of-wallis-island">The Ballad of Wallis Island</a>
</h3>

<div class="row style__cardScheduleItems___...">
  <div>
    <a class="style__screeningButtonLink___..." href="...">
      <span class="style__screeningDisplayTime___...">6:00pm</span>
    </a>
  </div>
  <div>
    <a class="style__screeningButtonLink___..." href="...">
      <span class="style__screeningDisplayTime___...">9:15pm</span>
    </a>
  </div>
</div>

Your current scraper likely just grabs the first time — but we want all showtimes, each as its own calendar entry.

✅ Fix: Loop Over All Showtime Buttons

Here's the updated scraping logic:

  1. For each event card:

  2. Extract the film title

  3. Loop over all .screeningDisplayTime elements

  4. For each one, build a separate event entry

🧾 Drop-In Fix for Your TIFF Scraper

Look for the part in your scrape_tiff.py where you're currently doing:

python
screening_time = parent.find_element(...).text
ticket_link = parent.find_element(...).get_attribute("href")

films.append({ ... })

🔁 Replace that with:

python
# Find all showtime buttons
showtime_buttons = parent.find_elements(By.CLASS_NAME, "style__screeningButtonLink___kUNSA")

for btn in showtime_buttons:
    try:
        time = btn.find_element(By.CLASS_NAME, "style__screeningDisplayTime___2VUn1").text.strip()
        ticket_link = btn.get_attribute("href")
        full_showtime = f"{date_str}, {time}"

        films.append({
            "title": title,
            "link": ticket_link,
            "showtime": full_showtime,
            "source": "TIFF Bell Lightbox"
        })
    except:
        continue

✅ What This Fixes

Now, if TIFF lists:

  • 🕕 6:00pm

  • 🕘 9:15pm

…for The Ballad of Wallis Island, your scraper will output:

json
[
  {
    "title": "The Ballad of Wallis Island",
    "showtime": "Tuesday May 13, 6:00pm",
    ...
  },
  {
    "title": "The Ballad of Wallis Island",
    "showtime": "Tuesday May 13, 9:15pm",
    ...
  }
]

✅ Which will show both screenings correctly in your calendar.
