ChatGPT said:

Absolutely — here’s your fully repackaged and fixed scrape_tiff.py that:

✅ Uses Selenium
✅ Extracts the film title and all showtimes per day
✅ Skips entries like Film Reference Library
✅ Outputs everything to tiff_films.json — ready for your calendar

🧾 Final scrape_tiff.py (Drop-in Ready)

python
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.service import Service
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.options import Options
import json
import time

CHROMEDRIVER_PATH = "D:/tools/chromedriver.exe"  # Update this if needed

options = Options()
# options.add_argument("--headless")  # Uncomment for headless mode
options.add_argument("--no-sandbox")
options.add_argument("--disable-dev-shm-usage")

service = Service(CHROMEDRIVER_PATH)
driver = webdriver.Chrome(service=service, options=options)

driver.get("https://tiff.net/calendar")
print("📄 TIFF Calendar loaded:", driver.title)

time.sleep(6)  # Allow Vue content to fully render

films = []

# Find daily sections on the calendar
day_sections = driver.find_elements(By.CLASS_NAME, "calendar-list-item")

print(f"✅ Found {len(day_sections)} calendar sections")

for section in day_sections:
    try:
        # Extract date text (e.g. "Today Apr 8" → "Apr 8")
        date_header = section.find_element(By.CLASS_NAME, "style__date___312bI").text.strip()
        parts = date_header.split()
        date_str = " ".join([p for p in parts if p not in ["Today", "Tomorrow"]])
    except:
        date_str = "Unknown Date"

    # Each film in the section
    title_cards = section.find_elements(By.CLASS_NAME, "style__cardTitle___3rkLd")

    for title_card in title_cards:
        try:
            title_tag = title_card.find_element(By.TAG_NAME, "a")
            title = title_tag.text.strip()
            if "Film Reference Library" in title:
                continue
            event_link = title_tag.get_attribute("href")
            full_event_link = f"https://tiff.net{event_link}" if event_link.startswith("/") else event_link
        except:
            title = "Untitled"
            full_event_link = None

        # Go up one level to find showtimes container
        try:
            parent = title_card.find_element(By.XPATH, "..")

            showtime_buttons = parent.find_elements(By.CLASS_NAME, "style__screeningButtonLink___kUNSA")

            for btn in showtime_buttons:
                try:
                    time_str = btn.find_element(By.CLASS_NAME, "style__screeningDisplayTime___2VUn1").text.strip()
                    ticket_link = btn.get_attribute("href")
                    full_showtime = f"{date_str}, {time_str}"

                    films.append({
                        "title": title,
                        "link": ticket_link,
                        "showtime": full_showtime,
                        "source": "TIFF Bell Lightbox"
                    })
                except:
                    continue

        except:
            continue

driver.quit()

# Save to JSON
with open("tiff_films.json", "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    json.dump(films, f, indent=2, ensure_ascii=False)

print(f"✅ Saved {len(films)} TIFF listings to tiff_films.json")

✅ What’s Fixed/Improved

  • All showtimes per title are now captured individually

  • Filters out non-screenings like Film Reference Library

  • Generates accurate showtime strings like:
    "Tuesday May 13, 6:00pm"

🧪 After Running

  1. Run:

bash
python scrape_tiff.py

  1. Then regenerate your calendar:

bash
python generate_calendar_grid.py

  1. ✅ Open calendar_grid.html and confirm:

    • The Ballad of Wallis Island shows all showtimes

    • Multiple screenings per day appear as separate entries

Great question — and yes, you can automate and publish your calendar to the web, even with Selenium in the mix — but there are a few important considerations depending on your approach.

Let’s break it down:

✅ Goal

You want to:

  1. 🧹 Scrape theaters automatically (even ones needing Chrome/Selenium)

  2. 🧾 Generate calendar_grid.html

  3. 🌐 Publish that file to the web on a schedule

✅ Option 1: Run Locally + Auto-Publish to GitHub Pages

This is the easiest and most flexible option:

🛠 How It Works:

  1. You run your update_calendar.py script on your computer (or server)

  2. It scrapes with Chrome (works fine locally)

  3. Then pushes the updated calendar_grid.html to a GitHub repo (e.g. main)

  4. GitHub Pages serves the latest calendar

🧰 What You Need:

  • A GitHub repo set up with Pages enabled

  • A local script that:

    • Commits the updated file

    • Pushes to GitHub

✅ Example publish_to_github.py:

python
import subprocess

# Add & commit updated calendar
subprocess.run(["git", "add", "calendar_grid.html"])
subprocess.run(["git", "commit", "-m", "📅 Auto-update calendar"])
subprocess.run(["git", "push"])

Then just run this after your update script, or combine both into one:

bash
python update_calendar.py && python publish_to_github.py

⏰ Automate via:

  • Windows Task Scheduler

  • Mac/Linux cron

✅ Pros:

  • Fully customizable

  • Easy to automate

  • You control everything

✅ Option 2: Host on a VPS or Raspberry Pi

If you want it running 24/7 without your computer:

  • Host on a VPS (like DigitalOcean, Linode, etc.) or a Raspberry Pi

  • Install Chrome + chromedriver + Python

  • Schedule your master update script using cron

  • Serve the output using nginx, apache, or just upload to GitHub Pages as above

✅ Pros:

  • Completely automated + headless

  • Fully private and self-hosted

⚠️ Option 3: Serverless (Netlify/Render/Cloud Functions)

❌ Not great if you need Selenium (Chrome GUI required)

These platforms:

  • Don’t allow launching a full browser easily

  • Are better suited for lightweight scrapers using requests + BeautifulSoup

⚠️ So if your scraper requires Selenium, you're better off generating locally and uploading the results.

✅ Summary

ApproachUses Chrome?Auto-Updatable?Ideal For
🖥️ Local + GitHub Pages✅ Yes✅ Yes (via cron/task)Simple publishing
🌐 VPS or Raspberry Pi✅ Yes✅ YesFull autonomy & automation
☁️ Netlify/Cloud Functions❌ No⚠️ Yes (limited)Headless scrapers only

Stick with local automation + GitHub Pages for now:

  • You already have a working master script

  • You only need to add a git push step

Thanks for sharing the full traceback — this error is super common and easy to fix! 💡

🧨 What’s Going Wrong?

This part is key:

arduino
FileNotFoundError: [WinError 2] The system cannot find the file specified

It means Python can't find the git command.

✅ Fix in One of Two Ways

✅ Option 1: Make Sure Git is Installed and on Your PATH

  1. Open Command Prompt

  2. Type:

bash
git --version

If you see:

nginx
git version 2.xx.xx.windows.x

✅ You're good. Skip to the script fix below.

If you see:

csharp

means that the script is not being run inside a Git repository, so the git add, commit, and push commands are failing silently.

🧠 Why This Happens

Your update_calendar.py is trying to run Git commands, but it's running from a folder that’s not inside your GitHub project (i.e., doesn’t contain a .git folder).

✅ How to Fix It

You have two easy options:

✅ Option 1: Move Your Calendar Project Into Your Cloned Git Repo

  1. Go to GitHub and create your repo (if you haven't yet):
    👉 https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/toronto-rep-calendar

  2. In Command Prompt:

    • update_calendar.py

    bash

python update_calendar.py

✅ This will now run Git properly!

✅ Option 2: Tell the Script Where the Repo Lives

If you want to keep your scripts elsewhere, you can change your script to do this:

python
import subprocess
import os

# Path to your Git repo folder
repo_path = r"D:\path\to\toronto-rep-calendar"

os.chdir(repo_path)

# Run Git commands
print("📤 Publishing calendar to GitHub Pages...")
subprocess.run(["git", "add", "calendar_grid.html"])
subprocess.run(["git", "commit", "-m", "📅 Auto-update calendar"])
subprocess.run(["git", "push"])

This tells Python to "act as if it's inside your GitHub folder."

You said:
Can we adjust the filters so we can select and deselect theaters? Allowing people to view more than one theatre at a time but not always all?
ChatGPT said:

Yes! Let's upgrade your theater filter to a multi-select toggle system 🔘 — so people can:

✅ Select multiple theaters
✅ Deselect any they don't want
✅ Filter live in both Grid and List view
✅ Without using a dropdown

✅ What We’ll Build Instead of a Dropdown:

A group of toggle buttons (like pills or checkboxes), e.g.:

css
[☑️ Revue] [☑️ Paradise] [☐ TIFF]

You can click any combo: just TIFF, or TIFF + Revue, or all three — fully dynamic.

🧠 How It Works

  • Each .film has data-source="Paradise Theatre" etc.

  • JavaScript keeps track of which sources are toggled on

  • It hides any film that doesn't match an active source

🧾 Step-by-Step Code Changes

✅ 1. In your <body> → Replace the dropdown filter with this:

html
<div class="filters">
  <label>🎭 Filter by Theater:</label>
  <div class="toggle-filters">
    <button class="toggle active" data-source="Revue Cinema">Revue</button>
    <button class="toggle active" data-source="Paradise Theatre">Paradise</button>
    <button class="toggle active" data-source="TIFF Bell Lightbox">TIFF</button>
  </div>
</div>

✅ 2. In your <style> block, add styles for the buttons:

css
.toggle-filters {
  display: flex;
  flex-wrap: wrap;
  gap: 0.5rem;
  margin: 0.5rem 0 1.5rem;
}

.toggle {
  padding: 0.4rem 1rem;
  font-size: 0.9rem;
  border-radius: 20px;
  border: 1px solid #aaa;
  background-color: #f0f0f0;
  cursor: pointer;
}

.toggle.active {
  background-color: #333;
  color: white;
  border-color: #333;
}

✅ 3. In your <script>, replace filterTheater(...) with this:

html
<script>
  const activeSources = new Set(["Revue Cinema", "Paradise Theatre", "TIFF Bell Lightbox"]);

  function updateFilters() {
    document.querySelectorAll('.film').forEach(film => {
      const source = film.getAttribute('data-source');
      film.style.display = activeSources.has(source) ? 'block' : 'none';
    });

    document.querySelectorAll('.day-box, .list-day').forEach(day => {
      const visible = day.querySelectorAll('.film:not([style*="display: none"])').length > 0;
      day.style.display = visible ? 'block' : 'none';
    });
  }

  function toggleFilter(button) {
    const source = button.getAttribute('data-source');
    if (activeSources.has(source)) {
      activeSources.delete(source);
      button.classList.remove('active');
    } else {
      activeSources.add(source);
      button.classList.add('active');
    }
    updateFilters();
  }

  window.onload = function () {
    updateFilters();

    document.querySelectorAll('.toggle').forEach(btn => {
      btn.addEventListener('click', () => toggleFilter(btn));
    });

    toggleView('grid-view');  // default view
  }
</script>

✅ Done!

  • 🔄 Works with both Grid and List views

import json
from datetime import datetime
from collections import defaultdict
from dateutil import parser

# === Load JSON files ===
def load_json(path):
with open(path, "r", encoding="utf-8") as f:
return json.load(f)

revue = load_json("revue_films.json")
paradise = load_json("paradise_films.json")
tiff = load_json("tiff_films.json")

# === Combine and parse ===
all_films = revue + paradise + tiff
date_map = defaultdict(list)
months = set()

for film in all_films:
raw = film["showtime"]
try:
dt = parser.parse(raw)
except:
continue

date_key = dt.strftime("%Y-%m-%d")
readable_date = dt.strftime("%A, %B %d")
month_key = dt.strftime("%B %Y")
time_str = dt.strftime("%I:%M %p")

months.add(month_key)
date_map[date_key].append({
"readable": readable_date,
"time": time_str,
"title": film["title"],
"link": film["link"],
"source": film.get("source", "Unknown"),
"month": month_key
})

# === Sort data ===
sorted_dates = sorted(date_map.keys())
sorted_months = sorted(months, key=lambda m: datetime.strptime(m, "%B %Y"))

# === CSS-safe classes ===
theater_classes = {
"Revue Cinema": "revue",
"Paradise Theatre": "paradise",
"TIFF Bell Lightbox": "tiff"
}

# === Start HTML ===
html = open("calendar_template.html", "r", encoding="utf-8").read()

# === Generate Grid View Content ===
grid_html = ""
for month in sorted_months:
grid_html += f"<h2>{month}</h2>\n<div class='grid'>\n"
for date in sorted_dates:
films = date_map[date]
if not films or films[0]["month"] != month:
continue
grid_html += f"<div class='day-box'><h3>{films[0]['readable']}</h3>"
for film in sorted(films, key=lambda x: x["time"]):
css = theater_classes.get(film["source"], "default")
grid_html += (
f"<div class='film' data-source='{film['source']}'>"
f"<span class='time'>{film['time']}</span>"
f"<a href='{film['link']}' target='_blank'>{film['title']}</a><br>"
f"<span class='label {css}'>{film['source']}</span>"
f"</div>"
)
grid_html += "</div>\n"
grid_html += "</div>\n"

# === Generate List View Content ===
list_html = ""
for date in sorted_dates:
films = date_map[date]
list_html += f"<div class='list-day'><h2>{films[0]['readable']}</h2>\n"
for film in sorted(films, key=lambda x: x["time"]):
css = theater_classes.get(film["source"], "default")
list_html += (
f"<div class='film' data-source='{film['source']}'>"
f"<span class='time'>{film['time']}</span>"
f"<a href='{film['link']}' target='_blank'>{film['title']}</a>"
f"<span class='label {css}'>{film['source']}</span>"
f"</div>\n"
)
list_html += "</div>\n"

# === Insert content ===
html = html.replace("<!-- your grid content goes here -->", grid_html)
html = html.replace("<!-- your list content goes here -->", list_html)

# === Save HTML ===
with open("index.html", "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
f.write(html)

print("✅ Created index.html with mobile optimization and multi-filter support.")
